required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study Evaluating Desvenlafaxine Succinate Sustained Release (DVS SR) vs. Escitalopram in Postmenopausal Women
clinical_study.official_title: A Multicenter, Randomized, 8-Week Double-Blind Acute Phase Followed By a 6-Month Continuation Phase (Open-Label Or Double-Blind) Study to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of DVS SR Versus Escitalopram in Postmenopausal Women With Major Depressive Disorder

lead_sponsor.agency: Wyeth is now a wholly owned subsidiary of Pfizer

clinical_study.source: Wyeth is now a wholly owned subsidiary of Pfizer

brief_summary.textblock: Desvenlafaxine succinate (DVS) is a potent and selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). This study will investigate the safety, efficacy, and tolerability of DVS SR versus escitalopram in women with major depressive disorder (MDD) who are postmenopausal.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) Score From Baseline to Week 8
primary_outcome.description: HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Items are scored on either a 3 point (0 to 2) or a 5 point scale (0 to 4) with 0=none/absent and 4=most severe,for a maximum total score of 50. Change= 8 week adjusted mean HAM-D17 minus baseline adjusted mean HAM-D17.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Achieving Response to Treatment at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Acute Phase)
secondary_outcome.description: A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Achieving Remission at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Acute Phase)
secondary_outcome.description: Remission is defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score of ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical Global Impression Improvement (CGI-I) Score at 8 Weeks
secondary_outcome.description: CGI-I is a global rating scale that measures disease improvement. Using a 7-point scale, the clinician rates how much the patient's illness has improved or worsened relative to the baseline status (1= very much improved; 7= very much worse).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Clinical Global Impression Severity (CGI-S) Score From Baseline to Week
secondary_outcome.description: CGI-S is a global rating scale that measures the severity of a patient's disease. Using a 7-point scale, the clinician rates the severity of the patient's mental illness at the time of the assessment, relative to the clinician's experience with patients who have the same diagnosis (1= normal; 7= extremely ill).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Anxiety From Baseline to Week 8 (HAM-A) Score
secondary_outcome.description: The HAM-A is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 14 items characteristically associated with major anxiety disorders. Items are scaled 0 - 4 (0=none and 4=very severe), with a maximum total score of 56. Change= 8 week adjusted mean HAM-A total score minus baseline adjusted mean total score.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Dimension Health State EuroQol (EQ-5D) Score From Baseline to Week 8
secondary_outcome.description: EQ-5D is a standardized, subject-administered measure of health outcome. It provides a descriptive profile for 5 dimensions (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, anxiety/depression), using 3 levels (no, moderate, or extreme problems) and a single index value characterizing current health status using a 100-point visual analog scale (0=worst, 100=best). EQ-5D summary index is obtained with a formula that weights each level of the dimensions. The index-based score is interpreted along a continuum of 0 (death) to 1 (perfect health). Change=8 week score minus baseline score.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Responders Maintaining Response to Treatment at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Double Blind Continuation Phase)
secondary_outcome.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued the same treatment in a 6-month DB continuation phase and were evaluated to see if the response was maintained. A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Responders Achieving Remission at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Double Blind Continuation Phase)
secondary_outcome.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued the same treatment in a 6-month DB continuation phase and were evaluated to see if remission was achieved. Remission is defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score of ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Responders Improving Response to Remission During 6-month Double Blind Continuation Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment (Responders) at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued into a 6-month DB phase. Responders without remission at 8 weeks were assessed for remission status during the 6-month continuation. Remission defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale assessing 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Non-Responders Achieving Response at Final Evaluation of 6-month Open-Label (OL)Extension Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Patients who didn't achieve a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind phase entered into an OL treatment phase with DVS SR for 6 months and were evaluated to see if a response was achieved. A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Non-Responders Achieving Remission at Final Evaluation of 6-month Open-Label Extension Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Patients who did not achieve a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind phase entered into an open label (OL) treatment phase with DVS SR for 6 months and were evaluated to see if remission was achieved. Remission is defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score of ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Discontinuation-Emergent Signs and Symptoms (DESS) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: DESS is a clinician-administered 43-item assessment that evaluates discontinuation-emergent symptoms resulting from the withdrawal from test article. The DESS total score is the sum of the number of new symptoms and old (but worse) symptoms that appeared during tapering of the test article. A higher score indicates more symptoms. The DESS score was assessed by status of taper.

intervention.description: flexible dose of DVS 50-100 or 200 mg every day during 56 days. Extension until 6 months.
Flexible dose of Escitalopram 10 or 20 mg every day during 56 days. Extension until 6 months.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Postmenopausal women between the ages of 40 and 70 years, inclusive.
- A primary diagnosis of MDD, single or recurrent episode, without psychotic features using the modified MINI International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI).
- Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) total score > or = 22 at the screening and baseline visit.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Use of oral estrogen-, progestin-, androgen-, or Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM)-containing drug products 8 weeks before baseline.
- Current (within 12 months) psychoactive substance abuse or dependence (including alcohol), manic episode, post-traumatic stress disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, or a lifetime diagnosis of bipolar or psychotic disorder.
- A history or active presence of clinically important medical disease.
Additional criteria apply.

overall_official.affiliation: Wyeth is now a wholly owned subsidiary of Pfizer

responsible_party.name_title: Wyeth (Registry Contact: Clinical Trial Registry Specialist)

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subjects were recruited in Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and the United States from December 2006 to January 2008.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Subjects were screened up to 4 weeks.

group.title: Desvenlafaxine Succinate Sustained-release (DVS SR)
group.description: Acute Double Blind (DB) Phase Days 1 to 7: DVS SR 50 mg/day Days 8 to 14: 100 mg/day Days 15 to 56: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases Double Blind Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) Days 57-238: continue taking DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day Open-Label (OL) Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63: DVS SR 100 mg/day Days 64-238: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation: If patient taking DVS SR 200 mg/day, then decreased to 100 mg for 7 days, and then decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100 mg/day decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days.

group.title: Escitalopram
group.description: Acute DB Phase Days 1-14:escitalopram 10mg/day; Days 15-56:discretion of the investigator patients assigned escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases DB Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved 50% from baseline) Days 57-238:continue taking escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day OL Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63:DVS SR 100mg/day; Days 64-238:At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation:If patient taking DVS SR 200mg/day, decreased to 100mg/day for 7 days, and then decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100mg/day decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. If patients taking escitalopram 20mg/day, decreased to 10mg/day for 7 days and then decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days. Patients taking escitalopram 10mg/day decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days.

group.title: Desvenlafaxine Succinate Sustained-release (DVS SR)
group.description: Acute Double Blind (DB) Phase Days 1 to 7: DVS SR 50 mg/day Days 8 to 14: 100 mg/day Days 15 to 56: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases Double Blind Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) Days 57-238: continue taking DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day Open-Label (OL) Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63: DVS SR 100 mg/day Days 64-238: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation: If patient taking DVS SR 200 mg/day, then decreased to 100 mg for 7 days, and then decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100 mg/day decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days.

group.title: Escitalopram
group.description: Acute DB Phase Days 1-14:escitalopram 10mg/day; Days 15-56:discretion of the investigator patients assigned escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases DB Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved 50% from baseline) Days 57-238:continue taking escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day OL Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63:DVS SR 100mg/day; Days 64-238:At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation:If patient taking DVS SR 200mg/day, decreased to 100mg/day for 7 days, and then decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100mg/day decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. If patients taking escitalopram 20mg/day, decreased to 10mg/day for 7 days and then decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days. Patients taking escitalopram 10mg/day decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Change in Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) Score From Baseline to Week 8
outcome.description: HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Items are scored on either a 3 point (0 to 2) or a 5 point scale (0 to 4) with 0=none/absent and 4=most severe,for a maximum total score of 50. Change= 8 week adjusted mean HAM-D17 minus baseline adjusted mean HAM-D17.
outcome.population: Acute Double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥ 18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

If patients taking escitalopram 20mg/day, decreased to 10mg/day for 7 days and then decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days. Patients taking escitalopram 10mg/day decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days.

measure.title: Change in Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) Score From Baseline to Week 8
measure.description: HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Items are scored on either a 3 point (0 to 2) or a 5 point scale (0 to 4) with 0=none/absent and 4=most severe,for a maximum total score of 50. Change= 8 week adjusted mean HAM-D17 minus baseline adjusted mean HAM-D17.
measure.population: Acute Double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥ 18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

analysis.method_desc: Mixed Models Repeated Measures (MMRM) with baseline score as a covariant and factors for center, week and treatment.
analysis.estimate_desc: DVS SR adjusted mean change minus ESC adjusted mean change.

outcome.title: Percentage of Patients Achieving Response to Treatment at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Acute Phase)
outcome.description: A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
outcome.population: Acute double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

measure.title: Percentage of Patients Achieving Response to Treatment at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Acute Phase)
measure.description: A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
measure.population: Acute double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

analysis.method_desc: Logistic regression model with treatment and site as factors and baseline score as a covariant.
analysis.estimate_desc: Estimated odds ratio of DVS SR to ESC. Odd ratio adjusted for baseline, treatment and site.

outcome.title: Percentage of Patients Achieving Remission at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Acute Phase)

HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
outcome.population: Acute double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

measure.title: Change in Clinical Global Impression Severity (CGI-S) Score From Baseline to Week
measure.description: CGI-S is a global rating scale that measures the severity of a patient’s disease. Using a 7-point scale, the clinician rates the severity of the patient’s mental illness at the time of the assessment, relative to the clinician’s experience with patients who have the same diagnosis (1= normal; 7= extremely ill).
measure.population: Acute double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, took at least1 dose of study drug and had at least1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

analysis.method_desc: Mixed Models Repeated Measures (MMRM) with baseline score as a covariant and factors for center, week and treatment.
analysis.estimate_desc: DVS SR minus ESC adjusted mean

outcome.title: Change in Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Anxiety From Baseline to Week 8 (HAM-A) Score
outcome.description: The HAM-A is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 14 items characteristically associated with major anxiety disorders. Items are scaled 0 - 4 (0=none and 4=very severe), with a maximum total score of 56. Change= 8 week adjusted mean HAM-A total score minus baseline adjusted mean total score.
outcome.population: Acute Double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥ 18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

group.title: Desvenlafaxine Succinate Sustained-release (DVS SR)
group.description: Acute Double Blind (DB) Phase Days 1 to 7: DVS SR 50 mg/day Days 8 to 14: 100 mg/day Days 15 to 56: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases Double Blind Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) Days 57-238: continue taking DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day Open-Label (OL) Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63: DVS SR 100 mg/day Days 64-238: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation: If patient taking DVS SR 200 mg/day, then decreased to 100 mg for 7 days, and then decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100 mg/day decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days.

group.title: Escitalopram
group.description: Acute DB Phase Days 1-14:escitalopram 10mg/day; Days 15-56:discretion of the investigator patients assigned escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases DB Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved 50% from baseline) Days 57-238:continue taking escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day OL Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63:DVS SR 100mg/day; Days 64-238:At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation:If patient taking DVS SR 200mg/day, decreased to 100mg/day for 7 days, and then decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100mg/day decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. If patients taking escitalopram 20mg/day, decreased to 10mg/day for 7 days and then decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days. Patients taking escitalopram 10mg/day decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days.

measure.title: Change in Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Anxiety From Baseline to Week 8 (HAM-A) Score
measure.description: The HAM-A is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 14 items characteristically associated with major anxiety disorders. Items are scaled 0 - 4 (0=none and 4=very severe), with a maximum total score of 56. Change= 8 week adjusted mean HAM-A total score minus baseline adjusted mean total score.
measure.population: Acute Double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥ 18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

analysis.method_desc: Mixed model Repeated Measures (MMRM) analysis adjusted mean score for baseline score, time and center.
analysis.estimate_desc: DVS SR adjusted mean change minus ESC adjusted mean change.

outcome.title: Change in Dimension Health State EuroQol (EQ-5D) Score From Baseline to Week 8
outcome.description: EQ-5D is a standardized, subject-administered measure of health outcome. It provides a descriptive profile for 5 dimensions (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, anxiety/depression), using 3 levels (no, moderate, or extreme problems) and a single index value characterizing current health status using a 100-point visual analog scale (0=worst, 100=best). EQ-5D summary index is obtained with a formula that weights each level of the dimensions. The index-based score is interpreted along a continuum of 0 (death) to 1 (perfect health). Change=8 week score minus baseline score.
outcome.population: Acute Double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥ 18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

group.title: Desvenlafaxine Succinate Sustained-release (DVS SR)
group.description: Acute Double Blind (DB) Phase Days 1 to 7: DVS SR 50 mg/day Days 8 to 14: 100 mg/day Days 15 to 56: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases Double Blind Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) Days 57-238: continue taking DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200 mg/day Open-Label (OL) Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63: DVS SR 100 mg/day Days 64-238: At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100 mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation: If patient taking DVS SR 200 mg/day, then decreased to 100 mg for 7 days, and then decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100 mg/day decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days.

group.title: Escitalopram
group.description: Acute DB Phase Days 1-14:escitalopram 10mg/day; Days 15-56:discretion of the investigator patients assigned escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day 6-Month Continuation Phases DB Continuation Phase for Responders (HAM-D17 improved 50% from baseline) Days 57-238:continue taking escitalopram 10mg/day or 20mg/day OL Extension Phase for Non-Responders (HAM-D17 improved <50% from baseline) Days 57-63:DVS SR 100mg/day; Days 64-238:At the discretion of the investigator, patients assigned DVS SR 100mg/day or 200mg/day Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation:If patient taking DVS SR 200mg/day, decreased to 100mg/day for 7 days, and then decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100mg/day decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. If patients taking escitalopram 20mg/day, decreased to 10mg/day for 7 days and then decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days. Patients taking escitalopram 10mg/day decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days.

measure.title: Change in Dimension Health State EuroQol (EQ-5D) Score From Baseline to Week 8
measure.description: EQ-5D is a standardized, subject-administered measure of health outcome. It provides a descriptive profile for 5 dimensions (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, anxiety/depression), using 3 levels (no, moderate, or extreme problems) and a single index value characterizing current health status using a 100-point visual analog scale (0=worst, 100=best). EQ-5D summary index is obtained with a formula that weights each level of the dimensions. The index-based score is interpreted along a continuum of 0 (death) to 1 (perfect health). Change=8 week score minus baseline score.
measure.population: Acute Double-blind phase; all randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥ 18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation.

analysis.method_desc: Mixed Model Repeated Measures (MMRM) with treatment, time and site as factors and baseline as covariant.
analysis.estimate_desc: DVS SR adjusted mean change minus ESC adjusted mean change

outcome.title: Percentage of Responders Maintaining Response to Treatment at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Double Blind Continuation Phase)
outcome.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued the same treatment in a 6-month DB continuation phase and were evaluated to see if the response was maintained. A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
outcome.population: All randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug, had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation, achieved a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8) and continued treatment in the double blind continuation phase.

group.title: DVS SR Responders / DVS SR DB
group.description: Patients who received DVS SR during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), achieved a response to treatment (defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase and continued on DVS SR during the 6-month Double Blind Continuation phase.

group.title: ESC Responders / ESC DB
group.description: Patients who received ESC during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), achieved a response to treatment (defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase and continued on ESC during the 6-month Double Blind Continuation phase.

measure.title: Percentage of Responders Maintaining Response to Treatment at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Double Blind Continuation Phase)
measure.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued the same treatment in a 6-month DB continuation phase and were evaluated to see if the response was maintained. A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
measure.population: All randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug, had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation, achieved a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8) and continued treatment in the double blind continuation phase.

analysis.estimate_desc: Estimated odds ratio of DVS SR to ESC. Odd ratio adjusted for baseline, treatment and site.

outcome.title: Percentage of Responders Achieving Remission at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Double Blind Continuation Phase)
outcome.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued the same treatment in a 6-month DB continuation phase and were evaluated to see if remission was achieved. Remission is defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score of ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
outcome.population: All randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug, had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation, achieved a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8) and continued treatment in the double blind continuation phase.

group.title: DVS SR Responders / DVS SR DB
group.description: Patients who received DVS SR during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), achieved a response to treatment (defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase and continued on DVS SR during the 6-month Double Blind Continuation phase.

group.title: ESC Responders / ESC DB
group.description: Patients who received ESC during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), achieved a response to treatment (defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase and continued on ESC during the 6-month Double Blind Continuation phase.

measure.title: Percentage of Responders Achieving Remission at Final On-therapy Evaluation (Double Blind Continuation Phase)
measure.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued the same treatment in a 6-month DB continuation phase and were evaluated to see if remission was achieved. Remission is defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score of ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
measure.population: All randomized patients with a baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took at least 1 dose of study drug, had at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation, achieved a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8) and continued treatment in the double blind continuation phase.

analysis.estimate_desc: Estimated odds ratio of DVS SR to ESC. Odd ratio adjusted for baseline, treatment and site.

outcome.title: Percentage of Responders Improving Response to Remission During 6-month Double Blind Continuation Phase
outcome.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment (Responders) at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued into a 6-month DB phase. Responders without remission at 8 weeks were assessed for remission status during the 6-month continuation. Remission defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale assessing 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
outcome.population: All randomized patients with baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took ≥1 dose study drug, had ≥1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation, achieved a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) but not remission (HAM-D17 score ≤ 7) at the end of the acute phase and continued treatment in the 6-month DB continuation phase.

group.title: DVS SR Responders / DVS SR DB
group.description: Patients who received DVS SR during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), achieved a response to treatment (defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase and continued on DVS SR during the 6-month Double Blind Continuation phase.

group.title: ESC Responders / ESC DB
group.description: Patients who received ESC during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), achieved a response to treatment (defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase and continued on ESC during the 6-month Double Blind Continuation phase.

measure.title: Percentage of Responders Improving Response to Remission During 6-month Double Blind Continuation Phase
measure.description: Patients achieving a response to treatment (Responders) at the end of the 8-week acute double blind (DB) phase continued into a 6-month DB phase. Responders without remission at 8 weeks were assessed for remission status during the 6-month continuation. Remission defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale assessing 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
measure.population: All randomized patients with baseline HAM-D17 score ≥18, who took ≥1 dose study drug, had ≥1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation, achieved a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) but not remission (HAM-D17 score ≤ 7) at the end of the acute phase and continued treatment in the 6-month DB continuation phase.

outcome.title: Percentage of Non-Responders Achieving Response at Final Evaluation of 6-month Open-Label (OL)Extension Phase
outcome.description: Patients who didn't achieve a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind phase entered into an OL treatment phase with DVS SR for 6 months and were evaluated to see if a response was achieved. A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
outcome.population: All randomized patients who took at least 1 dose of study drug, who did not achieve a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8), entered into the open label extension phase and had baseline and at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation in the acute and open label phase.

group.title: DVS SR Non-Responders / DVS SR OL
group.description: Patients who received DVS SR during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), did not achieve a response to treatment (response defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase; entered into open label (OL) treatment with DVS SR during 6-month Open Label Extension phase.

group.title: ESC Non-Responders / DVS SR OL
group.description: Patients who received ESC during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), did not achieve a response to treatment (response defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase; entered into open label (OL) treatment with DVS SR during 6-month Open Label Extension phase.

measure.title: Percentage of Non-Responders Achieving Response at Final Evaluation of 6-month Open-Label (OL)Extension Phase
measure.description: Patients who didn't achieve a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind phase entered into an OL treatment phase with DVS SR for 6 months and were evaluated to see if a response was achieved. A response is defined as ≥ 50% decrease from baseline on Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
measure.population: All randomized patients who took at least 1 dose of study drug, who did not achieve a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8), entered into the open label extension phase and had baseline and at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation in the acute and open label phase.

outcome.title: Percentage of Non-Responders Achieving Remission at Final Evaluation of 6-month Open-Label Extension Phase
outcome.description: Patients who did not achieve a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind phase entered into an open label (OL) treatment phase with DVS SR for 6 months and were evaluated to see if remission was achieved. Remission is defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score of ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
outcome.population: All randomized patients who took at least 1 dose of study drug, who did not achieve a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8), entered into the open label extension phase and had baseline and at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation in the acute and open label phase.

group.title: DVS SR Non-Responders / DVS SR OL
group.description: Patients who received DVS SR during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), did not achieve a response to treatment (response defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase; entered into open label (OL) treatment with DVS SR during 6-month Open Label Extension phase.

group.title: ESC Non-Responders / DVS SR OL
group.description: Patients who received ESC during the acute double blind phase (weeks 1-8), did not achieve a response to treatment (response defined as HAM-D17 improved ≥50% from baseline) at the end of the acute phase; entered into open label (OL) treatment with DVS SR during 6-month Open Label Extension phase.

measure.title: Percentage of Non-Responders Achieving Remission at Final Evaluation of 6-month Open-Label Extension Phase
measure.description: Patients who did not achieve a response to treatment at the end of the 8-week acute double blind phase entered into an open label (OL) treatment phase with DVS SR for 6 months and were evaluated to see if remission was achieved. Remission is defined as a Hamilton Psychiatric Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D17) score of ≤ 7. HAM-D17 is a standardized, clinician-administered rating scale that assesses 17 items characteristically associated with major depression. Individual items are scored on a 0 to 2 or 4 scale (0=none/absent and 4=most severe) for a maximum total score of 50.
measure.population: All randomized patients who took at least 1 dose of study drug, who did not achieve a response to treatment (≥50% reduction of HAM-D17 total score from baseline) at the end of the acute phase (week 8), entered into the open label extension phase and had baseline and at least 1 post-baseline HAM-D17 evaluation in the acute and open label phase.

outcome.title: Discontinuation-Emergent Signs and Symptoms (DESS) Total Score
outcome.description: DESS is a clinician-administered 43-item assessment that evaluates discontinuation-emergent symptoms resulting from the withdrawal from test article. The DESS total score is the sum of the number of new symptoms and old (but worse) symptoms that appeared during tapering of the test article. A higher score indicates more symptoms. The DESS score was assessed by status of taper.
outcome.population: Safety population: Randomized patients who took ≥1 dose study drug. Excluded patients lost to follow-up and discontinued with < 4 wks therapy. Patients analyzed varied by time (DVS SR, ESC): End of Therapy (n=264, 267); Taper week 1 (n=217, 227); Taper week 2 (n=222, 223); Post-taper (n=219, 223).

group.title: Desvenlafaxine Succinate Sustained-Release (DVS SR)
group.description: Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation: If patient taking DVS SR 200 mg/day, then decreased to 100 mg/day for 7 days, and then decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days. Patients taking DVS SR 100 mg/day decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days.

group.title: Escitalopram (ESC)
group.description: Taper Phase Day 239 or at discontinuation: If patients taking escitalopram 20 mg/day, then decrease to 10 mg/day for 7 days and then decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days. Patients taking escitalopram 10 mg/day decreased to matching escitalopram placebo/day for 7 days.

measure.title: Discontinuation-Emergent Signs and Symptoms (DESS) Total Score
measure.description: DESS is a clinician-administered 43-item assessment that evaluates discontinuation-emergent symptoms resulting from the withdrawal from test article. The DESS total score is the sum of the number of new symptoms and old (but worse) symptoms that appeared during tapering of the test article. A higher score indicates more symptoms. The DESS score was assessed by status of taper.
measure.population: Safety population: Randomized patients who took ≥1 dose study drug. Excluded patients lost to follow-up and discontinued with < 4 wks therapy. Patients analyzed varied by time (DVS SR, ESC): End of Therapy (n=264, 267); Taper week 1 (n=217, 227); Taper week 2 (n=222, 223); Post-taper (n=219, 223).

analysis.groups_desc: DVS SR vs. ESC: end of therapy
DVS SR vs. ESC: after 1 week of taper
DVS SR vs. ESC: after 2 weeks of taper
DVS SR vs. ESC: after > 2 weeks of taper

Patients taking DVS SR 100 mg/day decreased to 50 mg/day for 7 days.

Patients taking DVS SR 100mg/day decreased to 50mg/day for 7 days. certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The PIs agreed to allow the sponsor 60 days to review and require changes to presentations or publications but only to protect confidential information and intellectual property, and for the sponsor to file a patent application, as applicable. The PIs also agreed for data to be presented first as a joint, multi-center publication.
